meta.name: description
meta.content:
Union Public Schools is a premiere Oklahoma district nationally recognized in four strategic areas: Early Childhood Education, Community Schools, STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math), and College/Career Readiness. Success in these areas is helping Union achieve its mission: “To Graduate 100% of Our Students College and/or Career-Ready.”
Union located in Tulsa is the seventh-largest district in Oklahoma, continuing its nearly 100-year tradition of spirit, pride and excellence. High expectations and impressive results have come to be known as “The Union Way.”

meta.content: Union, Union Public Schools, Tulsa, Oklahoma, public education, K-12, adult education, early childhood education, Redskins, Broken Arrow,

Seniors Kareem Ahmed and Madeline Addis, pictured in the center of the video, were named Mr. and Miss Union 2020. Being named Mr. and Miss Union is considered the highest honor a student may receive at Union High School.

Union High Alma Mater

Union High stands proud forever!
Loyalty rides high.
Memories, forget them never
As the years go by.
Friends, we make from year to year.
Watch as goals are reached
Union High will always be dear
To our destiny.

A few students even joined him on stage to show off their dance skills for “Old Town Road.”
Tobey talked a little about careers before singing. He comes to 2 Works for You from Suffolk University in Boston, Massachusetts, where he graduated with a major in broadcast journalism, and a minor in Spanish.
When he is not reporting, he is singing and came to Grove to share his talents. (He was a top 10 finalist in American Idol’s “Boston Idol” singing competition.)

Grove Elementary School - Friday, March 6
Union Public Schools
Tulsa, Oklahoma

#UnionSchools #BondDollarsatWork

Yes. It was loud.

Union 3rd, 4th, & 5th Grade students enjoyed a field trip to the Union Performing Arts Center Feb. 27, 2020, to perform in an interactive concert with the Tulsa Symphony Orchestra as part of the LinkUp program. 

More: https://www.unionps.org/236748_2?articleID=49175

Union was among the first of the local school districts to participate in the program with third grade students, which has grown so much that Union Fine Arts and music teachers offer two concerts for the three grades.

Through the Link Up program, students learn to play music on records, sing songs and eve reheare some dance steps with the music teacher. The culminating interactive performance with TSO brings it all together, and students really “discover how the orchestra sings.”

For more information, visit Winning Producer Returns to Alma Mater -","description":"Tony-Award winning producer Eric Cornell returned to his alma mater Thursday, Feb. 13, 2020, to talk with drama students at Union High School, 6636 S. Mingo Road, Tulsa, Oklahoma.

Cornell and his drama instructor Troy Powell talked about how Cornell convinced his instructor to let him join the Theatre of Professionals, which at the time did not allow freshmen.

But Cornell was persistent, and noted then and now, “it’s not about the age. It’s about the work.”

Powell agreed, saying Cornell made it possible for freshmen to be accepted into the program which has flourished since that time.

Cornell, of course, has flourished, winning Tony Award last summer for Best Revival of a Musical as one of the producers for the revival of "Oklahoma."

Cornell, who was voted "most dramatic boy" by his classmates in 2002, is co-producer of "To Kill A Mockingbird" and the national tour of “Hello Dolly.” His production company, Eric Cornell Productions, also has projects in television, music and consulting.

See: http://bit.ly/37ra6AO and https://www.ericcornellproductions.com/","thumbnails":{"default":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/hZwW1E0m0VQ/default.jpg","width":120,"height":90},"medium":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/hZwW1E0m0VQ/mqdefault.jpg","width":320,"height":180},"high":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/hZwW1E0m0VQ/hqdefault.jpg","width":480,"height":360},"standard":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/hZwW1E0m0VQ/sddefault.jpg","width":640,"height":480},"maxres":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/hZwW1E0m0VQ/maxresdefault.jpg","width":1280,"height":720}},"channelTitle":"UnionPublicSchools","playlistId":"PLOkJJdiqSDvVWyoyPBPvR3mukVNwNxwdC","position":25,"resourceId":{"kind":"youtube#video","videoId":"hZwW1E0m0VQ"}},"status":{"privacyStatus":"public"}},{"kind":"youtube#playlistItem","etag":""nxOHAKTVB7baOKsQgTtJIyGxcs8/0GmKqg7Hrk32MjiPns6z-hJKM-0"","id":"UExPa0pKZGlxU0R2Vld5b3lQQlB2UjNtdWtWTndOeHdkQy40MEYyNDcyNUI2ODA2NEE4","snippet":{"publishedAt":"2020-02-14T14:42:59.000Z","channelId":"UCo-OSe4qx4_ifi2PJAmK2Gg","title":"2020 STEM Expo: Team Bazinga","description":"We had an incredible time at STEM Expo 2020 here in the Union School District! Union Sophomore Recites "I Have a Dream" Speech","description":"Union High School sophomore Joseph Terrell won the 2020 "I Have a Dream" speech contest and recited it at ONE Gas, Inc., headquarters in downtown Tulsa Thursday, January 16. The Dr. Martin Luther King Jr Commemoration Society hosts an annual contest for one local high school student to receive the honor of delivering this powerful speech with a cash prize of $500, sponsored by ONE Gas. Congratulations, Joseph! We are proud of you! 

#MLKSpeech #UnionSchools #Ihaveadream","thumbnails":{"default":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/d3WEu53kxQM/default.jpg","width":120,"height":90},"medium":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/d3WEu53kxQM/mqdefault.jpg","width":320,"height":180},"high":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/d3WEu53kxQM/hqdefault.jpg","width":480,"height":360},"standard":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/d3WEu53kxQM/sddefault.jpg","width":640,"height":480},"maxres":{"url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/d3WEu53kxQM/maxresdefault.jpg","width":1280,"height":720}},"channelTitle":"UnionPublicSchools","playlistId":"PLOkJJdiqSDvVWyoyPBPvR3mukVNwNxwdC","position":38,"resourceId":{"kind":"youtube#video","videoId":"d3WEu53kxQM"}},"status":{"privacyStatus":"public"}},{"kind":"youtube#playlistItem","etag":""nxOHAKTVB7baOKsQgTtJIyGxcs8/9YdmSO7RtrW8tJNyB7_weqcQsIg"","id":"UExPa0pKZGlxU0R2Vld5b3lQQlB2UjNtdWtWTndOeHdkQy5DMTA1MDUzMEE2MTY1MTI4","snippet":{"publishedAt":"2020-01-16T13:46:21.000Z","channelId":"UCo-OSe4qx4_ifi2PJAmK2Gg","title":"Union Tuttle Stadium Demolished in Tulsa, Okla.","description":"After 43 years of serving the Union Public Schools family, Union Tuttle Stadium at Union High School has been torn down to make way for the new. See the first portion of the stadium tumble down safely. 

At about 10 a.m. January 9, 2020, Union began demolition on the west side of the stadium – originally built in 1976 – in preparation for the construction of a new $42 million stadium and fine arts facility, which also includes significant renovations in the high school. A crowd gathered to view the spectacle, including Dr. Wesley Jarman, superintendent when the stadium was first built in 1976, and Gil Cloud, former athletic director at the time. 

Retired Principal Dave Stauffer and Benny Dixon, another former athletic director (when the UMAC was built), also watched. The new stadium complex will include improved accessibility on the “home” side, including redesigned concessions and restroom facilities, as well as the creation of a new fine arts addition at the north end zone of the football field to serve the Union Renegade Regiment Marching Band. Teardown of the stadium’s west side will take six to eight weeks.

 The new stadium is expected to open in 2021, followed by the fine arts addition in 2022. In attendance at the demolition included Superintendent Dr. Kirt Hartzler; Associate Superintendent Charlie Bushyhead, who is leading construction of the new facility; Dr. Wesley Jarman (superintendent from 1975-1990), who oversaw the construction of the original stadium; and Gil Cloud, who formerly served as athletic director. 

“Union Tuttle Stadium has served us well for 43 years, but it’s time that we make improvements to better serve all of our students and patrons,” said Superintendent Kirt Hartzler. “We will make it up to our fans in the 2021 season, when we host more home games in a new stadium. It will definitely be worth the wait, as the fan experience will be greatly enhanced.” Union plans to host three or more football games next fall. Spectators will be temporarily reassigned to the east and north bleachers for the 2020 season. Other additions include a new wrestling practice area, an expanded weight room, and locker room, as well as a new press box. 

The final phase of the project will include high school interior renovations providing new spaces for the arts, volleyball and spirit groups. In the last two years alone, Union Tuttle Stadium has hosted 866 events. Union’s first varsity football game in the old stadium took place on September 24, 1976.

Related: https://www.unionps.org/236749_2?articleID=45740
